content.source_1: Wind turbines convert the kinetic energy of moving air (wind) into electricity.
content.source_2: Energy resources that harness wind are considered renewable because wind is replenished by ongoing atmospheric circulation driven by solar heating.
content.source_3: If something can be harnessed to generate electricity, it qualifies as an energy resource.
content.source_4: Large wind farms extract kinetic energy from the atmosphere and can measurably slow local wind speeds, reducing available wind energy within and downwind of the array.
content.source_5: In resource management, when the rate of extraction exceeds the rate of natural replenishment at the scale of use, the use is effectively non-renewable at that rate.
content.source_6: Meeting a large share of global energy demand with wind would require very extensive turbine deployments over vast areas, increasing cumulative extraction relative to the atmosphereâ€™s replenishment of kinetic energy.
